loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a 32 years old, married with two children.  Her children go to school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  Judith rents a one roomed house where she stays with ten people.  There is electricity and piped water at home.  The family gets three meals a day.  Judith resides and works seven days a week in a semi-urban area located in the outskirts of Kampala in Busega.  

Judith sells second hand clothes and receives at least 20 customers a day.  Besides this clothing business Judith is a teacher in a nearby school.  Judith has been with MCDT for five years and is servicing her eleventh loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.

loans.use: Buy bales of second hand clothing.

loans.name: Marl Nesly

texts.en:
Marl Nesly R. is from the village of Tumpagon Cagayan de  Oro City. She is 26 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marl Nesly has been in business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marl Nesly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI to purchase additional products to sell.  Marl Nesly is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business.  This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her store. 
---------------------------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Invest in expanding the business.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase additional goods for her business.

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
For a poor woman like Genoveva B. growing a business is quite hard, especially when what she makes in a day is barely enough to provide for her  family's needs. Moreover, Genoveva is the sole provider for her two dependent children.  Her eldest daughter is 26 years old and unemployed because of low educational attainment, and Genoveva's youngest is still in school and soon will be in high school which means she will be incurring more expenses for her education.

Though Genoveva was able to successfully repay the loan she took out last year, she chose not to increase the amount of loan she is requesting now. She plans to use this loan to buy rice for resale.  The basis for the small amount she has requested is her capacity to pay. Hopefully someday, her eldest daughter will be able to help Genoveva in her business, or will find a job and be able to help with the family's expenses. 

Despite the poverty her family suffers presently, Genoveva still hopes that someday their standard of living be changed.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale.

loans.name: Edencita

texts.en:
Edencita R. is from the village of Prk. A, Bonifacio, Lugait Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old and married with 7 adult children. She operates a business making and selling food — primarily snacks and other delicacies — from which she makes  approximately 4,000 PHP a month. 

In 2009, Edencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Edencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase raw ingredients. Edencita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Edencita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Prk. A, Bonifacio, Lugait, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mariam,

texts.en:
Mariam is 30 years old, married with three children between 9 and 13. She rents the family's home. They have three meals a day and her greatest monthly expense is food. Mariam has a stall selling charcoal seven days a week and normally receives 20 customers a day. She has been doing this for over three years. Prior to this she sold used clothes. Every morning she has to spend money on transportation. When she doesn't have the money she has to walk to her work which is about three miles away from her home. 

Mariam has worked with MCDT for five years because she finds it easy to understand the way they operate. She will use this loan to pay fees for her children's education and to pay her rent. She also wants to start up another used clothing business.

loans.use: To  invest in second hand clothing

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie E. is 29 years of age and her only child is five years old. Being poor and dependent to her husband’s small and sporadic income, Elsie is worried for her child’s future. In her heart and mind all she wants is the best for him and his future by finishing his education so he can find the best career for himself. To achieve this dream for her child she joined ASHI and has requested a loan to grow her small “sari-sari” (variety) store. Elsie is a woman filled with love and inspiration because her family stays together through good and bad times.

loans.use: To purchase variety of good to sell in her store.

loans.name: Gildanita

texts.en:
Gildanita L. is from the Lugait municipality in the province of Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Gildanita is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Gildanita operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. Her main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Gildanita earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gildanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gildanita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gildanita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items in order to expand product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gildanita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand product offering

loans.name: Floricita

texts.en:
Although an older woman, Floricita still wants to be productive. Thus, she is requesting a larger loan amount from Kiva through ASHI for her second loan. This loan will be used to grow her small sari-sari (variety) store, which was put up using profits from her previous business. Since two of her three children have their own families now, Floricita will use her proceeds to support the education of her youngest and only child dependent. She also wants to support the needs of her grandchildren, since their parents are also poor.

Floricita's dreams and ambitions for her children and grandchildren are why she has remained strong and determined to grow her business, despite being poor and widowed.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods to sell in her store, and to buy a hog/pig for fattening and selling

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 41-year-old widow with three children, ages 10, 18, and 20. All her children go to school. She rents a one-room house, living with four people. There is neither electricity nor water. She takes care of two orphans and is self-reliant. The family gets three meals a day.

Alice buys fish from Gaba landing site, one of the biggest sites in the city centre of Kampala. She uses public transportation to get back to her business place. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Alice works seven days a week and also rents her business premises. She gets an average of twenty customers per day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. She has been running this business for the last six years, and she has been with MCDT and the same group mates for six years. This is her thirteenth loan. Alice's major challenge is the rainy season, as her customers are inconvenienced and, at times, halt going to her for a drink. This is so, because her place of business is covered with mud and water during the rains. Thieves also break into her business and go away with her brew.

Alice is boastful of her improved standard of living and her business's progress. She is aspiring to buy some land for herself in order to construct a commercial house and earn some money from tenants.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of smoked fish

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is from the village of Prk. Bonifacio in the Lugait municipality of Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Elizabeth is married and has three grown children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk for her cafe business

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is a 50-year-old single mother of seven. Three of her children go to school. She owns a four-room house, where she lives with six people. Deborah takes care of additional family members. Her family has access to electricity and piped water, and they get three meals a day.

Deborah doesn't incur any transportation costs in shopping for her business, as she buys from her place of work from delivery trucks. She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Deborah works seven days a week. She receives an average of 25 customers per day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing price of beer and the rainy season, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her, because she works in an open place. She has been in this business for twelve years

Deborah's monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family, and medication. She has been with MCDT for ten years, and they are servicing her twentieth loan. Deborah joined MCDT because it was easy to work with and near her home. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger, and she would like to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer

loans.name: Bineba

texts.en:
R. Bineba is the mother of four children. She lives in Ntamulung, Cameroon.  

She has been with GHAPE since 2004 and has demonstrated a credit-worthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance at meetings, and support of her borrowing group. 

R. never had the opportunity to go to school because her parents could not afford her fees and needs, so she resorted to becoming a farmer in her youth. Sadly, her father finally died in 1990 and monkeys ate all her crops last year. She was financially down, but with the management skills she acquired from GHAPE, she was able to repay her loan. 

With this latest loan, R. is hoping to continue the business supported by her prior loans and add a motorbike business. She has requested a loan to purchase a motorbike and a few seedlings. The seedlings will eventually be farmed during the rainy season. R. is confident that her business will succeed, because her business has been successful for a long time.
  
She hopes to use the profits from her business to provide for the various needs of her family. As the sole provider for her family of four, R. hopes to increase her profits so she has enough to pay for her children’s school fees and provide for her family’s nourishment.  


About GHAPE:

R.'s loan will be provided by Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and seedlings for farming

loans.name: Sattar

texts.en: Sattar S. was born in 1964. He is married and has one child. S.'s family lives in the city of Baku. Sattar has been in his business for two years. He now needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Zamira Narmatova`s Group

texts.en:
Zamira is 50 years old. She has five daughters and one son. All her daughters are married and live separately. Her only son helps his father who is a welder. He makes metal doors in Nookat. They also have some land where they want to sow potatoes. It should be mentioned that Nookat is famous for its potatoes. This is her family's second source of income. Her husband wants to expand his business and run a big welding workshop.

Mahbuba, age 36, is a housewife. She has six children and most of them attend school. Her husband works in a local cement factory. He is a driver. This loan will be used to buy 1 milk cow, which will let them sell milk and milk products. The additional income will be very good for her family.

Sanabar is married with five children. Her husband is a farmer, and he is a member of a local agro cooperative. They also have land where they usually cultivate potatoes. Now, Sanabar and other family members are very busy because of the upcoming spring. This loan will used to buy fertilizer.

Ulanbek is 28 years old. He is married with one little daughter. She is only 10 months old. His wife works in a local school as a chemistry teacher. He resells livestock in Nookat. He is asking for the loan in order to increase his number of cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional commodities for her business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 40-year-old single mother of seven. Some of her children attend school. She owns a four-room house, where she lives with six people. Rose takes care of additional family members. Her family has no access to electricity or piped water, but they get three meals a day.

Rose doesn't incur any transportation costs in shopping for her business, as she buys from her place of work from delivery trucks. She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Rose works seven days a week. She receives an average of 25 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing price of bananas and the rainy season. The price of bananas increases due to transportation problems. The rainy season hinders her customers' ability to reach her, because she works in an open place. She has been in her business for ten years.

Rose's monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family, and medication. She has been with MCDT for five years, and they are servicing her tenth loan. Rose joined MCDT because it was easy to work with and near her home. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy bunches of bananas

loans.name: Elizabeth Wanjiru

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married lady and a mother of two sons. She is a farmer who keeps and rears chicken layers within the Ruaka Trading center. She has been in this business for the last four years. She sells eggs to hotels, schools and other organizations in Ruaka and its surroundings. Her husband James is also a businessman within the same town. 

Elizabeth was introduced to Kiva field partner KADET by a friend, and this will be her second loan. She has not borrowed from any other microfinance institutions before. She wants to use the money from this loan to add more chicks into her poultry business in the hopes that her output might increase.

She desires to see her business grow into a leading poultry farm in the area. Elizabeth hopes that growing her business will help her make more meny, and that this will improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy more chicks to raise as egg laying hens.

loans.name: Susie

texts.en:
Susie is married with one 26-year-old son. As a busy entrepreneur, she has been running a sari-sari (variety) store for almost twenty years. Her husband is a tricycle driver in the neighborhood.

Susie would like to receive a loan of 45,000 PHP in order to increase the inventory of goods sold in her sari-sari store. She is planning to purchase additional products such as rice, sugar, gasoline, eggs, and cooking oil. Susie believes that offering a wide assortment of goods to customers will increase traffic to her store and maintain customer loyalty in the community.

Since 1996, Susie has been a dedicated and model member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines. She has demonstrated regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.

Susie's long term goals are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her store, and start a savings account for her grandchild's education. Through hard work and determination, Susie is focused on improving her quality of life with the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders.

About ASHI:
Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as rice, sugar, gasoline, eggs, and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy palm nuts to make red palm oil

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is 42 years old and married with four children. She lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines. Her husband, Ramil, works in the farming business. To supply additional income for her family, Vivian is expanding the family farming business, which has been in operation for almost nineteen years.

Vivian would like to receive a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase raw materials, including corn seeds and fertilizer. Since 1999, Vivian has been a dedicated member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines. She is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, Vivian is hopeful that her expanded business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family's quality of life. She hopes to diversify her revenue in the long term by launching additional business endeavors, including a tricycle and jeepney business.

About ASHI:
Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials including corn seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Thank you for the first loan. Having borrowed the first loan of $1,200 to buy meat for re-sale, now Nizami needs a second loan of 2,000 AZN to again buy more meat for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy meat for re-sale

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: To supply additional income for her family, Merlita E. has been running a farm for almost 15 years. She is 46 years old, married and has two minor children. She lives in the province of Rizal with her husband, Amador. He is a farmer and works closely with Merlita. Merlita would like to receive a loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to purchase additional materials for her business including palay (rice seeds), insecticides and other supplies, and to cover labor expenses. Merlita believes that the loan will help to grow her farming business and be the drive for increased revenue. Mercedita has been a proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 1999. She is a dedicated member demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans. Her long-term goals are to maintain the profitability of her business, to build a concrete and durable home, and to support the education of her children. Merlita is hopeful that her farming business venture will continue to grow and improve the overall standard of living for her entire family. About ASHI Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank approach (GBA) to deliver credit to the poorest of the poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models for credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase palay (rice seeds), insecticides and other supplies, and to cover labor expenses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional cosmetics for her business

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is a hardworking man of age 49.  He has been operating a taxi business for fifteen years.  He was previously employed in a restaurant.  He is a member of Kiva field partner Faulu Kenya and previously took a loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings.

He says that since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been in a good position to save his money.  He has five children in school, hence he has requested for a loan of 47,750 Kenyan shillings to pay school fees for them.  He hopes to open a restaurant in the future.  He sees himself being financially independent.

loans.use: To pay school fees.

loans.name: Che

texts.en:
B. is a widow who has five children. She lives in Ntabessi Nkwen Mezam Division NWR- Cameroon. B. and her entire family live in a house with three rooms. She often has to battle some life challenges, including inadequate funds to pay tuition for her children, ill health, and death of close family members. “Things have really been difficult, even when I try very hard…” she said. 

She has borrowed and repaid four loans since she joined GHAPE in 2003. With previous loans, she grew vegetables. She is planning to expand this business. She is planning to use part of her loan to repair her house. She states that the business of vegetables has been quite successful in the past and she attributes the success to her business location, reasonable prices, good marketing skills and experience, and demand for her produce.  She is optimistic that she will make profit and provide for her family.

About GHAPE:

The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses statement, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Farming vegetables, repairing her house,  and buying of land

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more traditional African cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her business

loans.name: Luiza Mirbaeva's Group

texts.en: Luiza is 43 years old and has one daughter, a college student, who will be a financial officer in the future. Luiza has a food outlet but, due to various reasons, she had to stop her business. Now she is asking for the loan to resume it. She will buy mainly food. Luiza loves her daughter and is trying to provide her with the best that is available. Mavludahan, 50, is married with four children: two sons and two daughters. She is a nurse in the village medical centre and her husband works in the educational department. This loan will be used for consumer needs. Shyrmanhan is 47 years old. She is divorced and is raising two children. She is the head of a local veterinary service and also has additional income since she is involved in livestock breeding. She has been in this business for eight years, helped by her son. First she bred sheep but later started breeding cattle. Her loan will be used to buy a milk cow. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To resume operation of her food store

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is married to Tata Frankline. She is the mother of five children. She is currently requesting her third loan from GHAPE. She has been with GHAPE since 2007 and has demonstrated a credit-worthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance of meetings and support of her borrowing group. 

Vivian raises chickens and transports passengers on her motorcycle. With this latest loan, Vivian is hoping to continue the business supported by her prior loans. The fowl eventually will be sold on Foncha street and the motorbike will be roaming the Bamenda town carrying passengers. She is confident that her business will succeed because it is located in a strategic position within the market. She also feels that her friendly approach towards her customers also makes a big difference. 

Vivian hopes to use the profits from her business to provide for the various needs of her family. She hopes to increase her profits so she has enough to pay for her children’s school fees, open an account, and provide for her family’s nourishment. 

About GHAPE:

Her loan will be provided through the Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle, chickens, and chicken feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her business

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena D. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children.

Elena owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

Elena is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Avaz

texts.en: Avaz is applying for a second loan. To improve his business, he started a new business, a general store. He now needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy toys and products.

loans.use: To buy toys and products

loans.name: Numfor

texts.en:
S. is the mother of two children. They all live in the Ntabessi Mezam Division. S. is always smiling and says “…smiling is my therapy to overcome some of my stress”. She has not gone without bruises from the cruel hands of poverty, including inadequate money to pay for her children's school fees, buy medication, provide good food to her children, and to give a dignifying burial to her dear ones who past away to eternity. This she says has made life miserable some of the times but that in her trials she has learned how to smile.

Motivated by others in the program, she joined GHAPE in 2003. She has successfully managed and repaid five loans. With her fifth loan she is planning to stock medicines and piglets. With her experience in the business, she knows the business will greatly help the community, becuse they will be able to get drugs from her when they are sick and her pigs will provide pork meat for ceremonies and the manure for farm vegetables.


About GHAPE: 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses statement, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy drugs and piglets and to maintain her pig sty

loans.name: Pedra

texts.en: To make a living, Pedra B. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 60 years old, widowed and has three grown-up children. She is from the village of El Salvador, Misamis Oriental. Pedra has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Pedra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Pedra is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina has managed a small store since 1987. She sells coconut wine for PHP 200 per container. Then the income was used to buy the daily needs of her family. She continues to sells coconut wine because it is a very good business. She would like to increase her business through the help of a loan.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional coconut wine for her store.

loans.use: To buy additional coconut wine to resell

loans.name: Neba

texts.en:
E. is a mother of three children. She was abandoned by her husband when she was seriously ill and, by the grace of God, she recovered and put the husband to shame. She is the breadwinner of her family. She and her lovely children live in Mile Three Nkwen, Cameroon. E. said that, in the midst of the ups and downs in her life, she constantly told herself that “…I know God can turn my story around”, and that was when she heard about GHAPE. Identifying her group members was the only thing that delayed her enrollment. 

She joined the program in 2008 and has successfully managed and repay her first loan of forty thousand francs. With a second loan, she plans to expand her dress business. She plan to buy in bulk and sell to other final retailers who do not have capital, the position that she was in a few years ago. Hopeful that she will again register success with this loan, she plans to repay the loan in 12 months and use the additional income for the benefit of her family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses statement, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy wrappers, bags, and lace dresses

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma C. is from the village of Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Vilma is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. (Vilma C. is wearing a white shirt in her photo.)

In 2009, Vilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Vilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Nche

texts.en:
B. is the mother of four children currently living in Ntambessi, Cameroon. She is currently requesting her fourth loan from GHAPE. She has been with GHAPE since 2003 and has demonstrated a creditworthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance at meetings and support of her borrowing group.

With this latest loan B. is hoping to continue the business practices supported by her prior loans. She has requested the loan in order to purchase lumber and to pay for the labor of preparing the firewood for sale. She is confident that her business will continue to do well because of her experience in this industry. She understands her customers, their demands and the increasing need for firewood in her area. She is confident that her business will continue to provide revenue for her business and meet her family’s needs.

B. hopes to use the profits from her business to provide for her children. She utilizes the revenue from her business to provide her family with meals and to add an oil business. She will also be utilizing the revenue to take care of some personal medical needs.

B.’s loan will be provided through Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO (non-governmental organization) based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase timber, pay for labor, and buy corn beer and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Abylkasymova Zamira`s Group

texts.en:
Zamira is a woman with a hard fate. Her husband died many years ago and, unfortunately, she doesn't have any children. She lives with her brother's family. She works in a local school where she is a teacher. On weekends, she deals with animal sales in the local market. This loan will be used to buy cattle to resell later. Now she has eight cattle as trade assets. 

Bermet is 55 years old. She is also a widow with four children. Her elder daughter studies at the university. She deals with vegetable sales in Nookat. She sells mainly potatoes. This loan will be used to buy a cow. Her sons will help their mother look after it and she will sell milk and milk products. 

Busara, 52, has two sons. Both of them are pupils. She is involved in livestock breeding. She will use this loan to buy cattle to feed. She started this business four years ago with one sheep. Now she has a few cattle. 

Gulay is 44 years old. She lives with her sister and nieces. She works in the local library. In her free time, she looks after her cattle. She will buy cattle with her loan. Her average income from her business is $100 US.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en: Ma. Gina C., 44 years old, is a fish vendor. Her husband is a fisherman. She has five children and her eldest is already 29. She wants to improve her livelihood so that she can accommodate the needs of her family. She would like to request a loan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fishing materials and bait.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and bait

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy rice

loans.name: Mbonifor

texts.en:
H. is married with six children. He and his entire family live in a house with seven rooms in Ndamukong. This very hard working man joined GHAPE in 2008. H. has encountered some problems in life, such as the death of his father, mother, brother and child in 1992. He was also regrettably unable to continue school, which he loved so much. He became frustrated after he dropped out of school. Thanks to GHAPE, which was created at the time when he most needed it, H. resorted to thinking about going into business. He joined GHAPE and collected his first loan of 37,500 XAF to begin farming and selling firewood.

As a young talented man, even though things are not moving well with his family since his wife has undergone surgery, he is determined to make it in life. With the skills and trainings received from GHAPE, he has been able to improve his living standards. He farms and runs his firewood business for a living. He plans to invest this loan in buying firewood and seedlings along with feed for his piglets, bought with previous loans. H. has been quite successful in the past with his business and is now earning good profit from it due to the fact that he has lots of experience. Part of his profits from this loan will be used to take care of his children, buy necessities for the family and get good medication for them whenever they are sick. The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buy firewood and seedlings

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie T. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 26 years old. Ronie is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Ronie owns & operates a business providing trisikad (motorized tricycle) services to transport local community members. Ronie has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ronie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ronie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Komla Christophe

texts.en: Komla Christophe F. is 43 years old. He lives and works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo selling charcoal. He is married to a seamstress and has two children. Mr. F. began this business in 1998 and is now asking for his second loan from WAGES. He will use this loan to purchase 30 sacks of charcoal for resale. This loan will help support both his business and his family.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Sadig

texts.en: Sadig S. was born in 1982. He is married and has two children. Sadig and his family live in Baku city. He has been in this business for two years. Now this young man needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables.

Aside from seaweed, she is also managing a small sari-sari store business. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy seaweed seedlings.

The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling RTW shirts, shoes, bags and more in the local community. Monnena is just starting this business.

In 2010, Monnena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monnena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1firt loan taken out by Monnena from HSPFI. loans.name: Kalyskan Tagaeva`s Group

texts.en:
Kalyskan is 39 years old. She is divorced and has one son. He is a college student. She has been involved in a sewing business for more than 10 years. At present time, this is her main income of source. At the first stage, she rented a sewing machine. Later she had some savings and bought a sewing and overstitching machine. She mainly sews curtains and women's garments. She is asking for her first loan to buy sewing materials. 

Monuskan and Kalyskan are sisters. Monuskan, 37, is married with three children. Her husband is a foremaster. She is involved in animal breeding. She has cows, horses and sheep. This loan will be used to buy additional cattle. 

Kubatbek, 36, is married. His wife is a housewife and mainly looks after the animals. They have cows, horses and eight sheep. He wants a loan to buy five sheep. The increase in cattle will let her increase her overall family income. 

Zulayka is a widow. She has three sons. They always help their mother with the housework. She breeds animals. She started her business just two years ago with two sheep. Now she has three cows, two calves and two sheep. This is because of her hard work and enterprenurial skills. She hopes to increase the number of sheep, using this loan.
 
This is the first loan for all members of this group. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

loans.name: Aku Eunice

texts.en: Aku Eunice G. is 42 and married to an architect. She has three children and lives in Adidogomé, Togo. She works from home selling grocery products, grains and cereals. She began this business in 2007. This will be her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock. It is with great hope that this loan will allow Mrs. G.'s business to continue to grow and prosper.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for resale

loans.name: Huyagbat

texts.en: Huyagbat B. is a 37-year-old man whose family lives in Arhangay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Since 2000, he has been running a raw materials sales business. He buys animal skins, cashmere and wool from local herders and sells them at the local market or transports them to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia to sell for a better price. Besides this business, together with his spouse Saihantuya, he runs a retail stall at the local market. He purchases many of the household items at wholesale prices while traveling to the capital city, and sells them to local residents. Huyagbat and Saihantuya have three children. All their children go to the local elementary school. Huyagbat requests a loan to purchase more animal related raw material to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more animal skins

loans.name: Marusya

texts.en: Marusya J. is a 61-year-old lady who lives with her husband in Arhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. Her family lives in a ger, a Mongolian housing tent on the plot of land they own. Her husband, Batsuh, is a driver. Marusya has been running a small bakery shop since 2005. She bakes a variety of cakes, cookies and bread. As she is a very experienced baker, she could have many repeat clients who purchase her product on a daily basis. When she began her business, she had only 350,000 tugrugs. That is equal to $250 US. As a result of her five years of hard work, her working capital has increased 10 times. To increase her business inventory, she requests a loan to purchase ingredients such as flour, eggs, and sugar for her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Afi

texts.en: Afi P. is 40 years old. She is married to a chief construction worker and has three children. Mrs. P. roams the city of Lomé selling colorful fabrics for dressmaking. She began this business in 2005 and is now asking for her second loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to resupply her stock of fabrics. By ensuring that her stock is plentiful, she will be able to keep up with the high demand for this popular item.

loans.use: To purchase fabric to sell

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya D. is a 43 year old married mother of one son. Her son, Luvsandondog, attends the local elementary school. Since 2002, Sarantuya has run a clothing stall at the local market with her husband Lhagvasuren. When she started her business, she rented a stall. After a few years of hard work, she bought the stall she was renting.

They are planning to buy a condominium in next few months with the profits from their business. Sarantuya goes to Ereen, a city on the border with China, once a month to purchase a variety of apparel for men and women. She requests a loan to purchase spring clothing to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia A., 45 years old, is a sari-sari (variety) store owner. She has four children. The eldest is 22 years old and is helping her in manning the store. The income which she gained from selling various goods is very important because it is where they get enough money to buy the daily needs for their home. 

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc.  She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Shanta

texts.en:
Mrs. Shanta T. lives in a single family with her husband and three children. Both Mrs. T. and Mr. T. are engaged in agriculture. They own their own land for farming. Mostly they grow green vegetables on their land. They sell their vegetables at the local market in the morning and evening daily. They meet all the needs of their family with the income from their farming. 

Mrs. Shanta T. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishepati. Sainbu-Bhaishepati is located in the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. She has two daughters and one son. All of her children are now working.

Mrs. T. is requesting a 10,000 Nepalese rupee loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for the farm.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity is a 23-year-old single mother of one child who is in school. She has been running a retail shop, “Owuya’s Shop”, where she sells foodstuff, cosmetics, handbags, etc. She has been in this business for four years. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has grown financially and business-wise and has also learnt to manage business and finance.   She wants to be a prominent businesswoman and hopes to own a salon and a beauty shop in town in future.  

Purity has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a popcorn machine (for 32,000 KES), ladies handbags (for 
10,000 KES) and shoes (for 18,000 KES). She describes herself as courageous, a self-starter and God-fearing.

loans.name: Sulochana

texts.en:
Mrs. Sulochana S. is 35 years old and lives in Sainbu-Bhaishipati. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Most of the people in this area are engaged in agricultural farming. Mrs. S. lives together with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Tika Prasad S., is a broker who sells land. Her sons are in the 5th and 12th grades.

Mrs. S. opened her cosmetics shop five years ago. She wants to add other personal care products to her shop because the demand for these products is constantly increasing. Due to their economic conditions, however, she cannot invest in more capital for her business, so she is asking for her second loan of 20,000 NPR to buy more cosmetics for her shop. Mrs. S. spends her income on providing a good education for her children.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes and onions for her business.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married lady with two children. She runs a cereals shop at the Gitaru Trading Center. She has been in this business for the last two years. Her customers are largely small-scale traders and others who buy for direct consumption. Her husband Cyrus works as a driver, and they live in Gitaru, which is on the outskirts of the town of Nairobi.

Pauline was introduced to KADET by a friend, and this will be her first loan. She has no previous credit history with other microfinance institutions. She wants to use the money from this loan to buy more stock so she can increase her output. She plans to add things like a sack of beans, maize, and other similar items.

She hopes to see her business grow into a leading cereals supplier for the area. This will improve her living standards, and she will be able to better meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of cereals like beans and maize.

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en: Jeremiah is 50 years old and married with six children. Five of his children are in school. He has been running a spare-parts shop where he sells spare parts and tires for six years now. He earns extra income from small-scale farming. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to provide the basic needs for his family and pay his children's school fees. Jeremiah, who describes himself as aggressive and very enduring, hopes to open a very big spare-parts shop and garage in the future. He previously had a Faulu loan of 15,000 KES and is now requesting another loan of 30,000 KES to purchase more spare parts and tires.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts and tires.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 27 years old and married with one child who is in school. He has been running a retail shop for three years. He previously worked in the industrial area but now he earns extra living as a barber. Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to save his money. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to open other branches in the future.

John has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy sugar (for 5,000 KES), flour (for 10,000 KES) and cooking fat (for 5,000 KES).

loans.name: Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Maiya B. lives as a single family with her husband and one son. Her son is just a year old. Both Mrs. Malla and Mr. Malla are engaged in agriculture. They own their own land for farming. Mostly they grow green vegetables on their land. They sell their vegetables at the local market in the morning and evening daily. They meet all the needs of their family with their income from farming. 

Mrs. Maiya B. lives in Bhatkepati. Bhatkepati is located in the Kathmandu district and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. B. is requesting a 10,000 Nepalese rupee loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for the farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 35-year-old married woman with two children. She operates a retail shop at the Lower Kabete Trading Center where she sells food stuff like rice, sugar, cooking oil, bread and the likes.She has been in this business for two years. 
Her customers are largely small-scale traders and others who buy for direct consumption. 
Her husband, Peter, works as a taxi driver and they live in near her business, which is on the outskirts of Nairobi. 

Grace was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be her first loan. She has had no previous credit history with other micro-finance institutions. She wants to use the money from this loan to add more inventory to her shop. She wants to buy some charcoal and paraffin (fuel) to sell so that her income  can also increase.
 
She wants to see her business grow into a wholesale shop in the area. This will improve their livings standards and she will be able to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: Grace plans to buy some paraffin and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Dyne

texts.fr: Madame Dyne D. est une habitante de la localité de Yoff  dans le quartier de Ngaparou. Elle est âgée de 36 ans. Elle est divorcée et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1an1mois et 2 ans et demi. Comme activité  commerciale elle  s’active dans l’achat et la vente de thioubs  depuis plus de 7 ans. Parallèlement  elle est employée  pour faire le ménage dans une agence de nettoiement. Elle  a choisi cette activité  de vente de thioubs par l’influence de sa sœur  qui vit à Tamba. Ce qui l’intéresse  le plus dans cette activité c’est  l’aspect lucratif. Elle sollicite un crédit de 300 000 frs pour l’achat de thioubs en vue d’augmenter son niveau d’activité. L’accroissement de ses bénéfices lui permettra de mieux prendre en charge ses besoins personnels ainsi que ceux de sa famille. Son objectif est d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dyne D. lives in the town of Yoff in the Ngaparou district. She is 36 years old, divorced and mother to two children, whose ages range from 13 months to two and a half years old. She has had a business buying and selling "thioubs" (a special tinted fabric) for more than seven years. At the same time she is employed to do the cleaning by a cleaning agency. It was the influence of her sister, who lives in Tamba, that led her to choose the "thioub" selling business. What interests her most about this business is that it is lucrative. She is applying for a loan of 300,000 francs in order to buy "thioubs" and increase her business volume. The growth in her profits will allow her to cover her personal needs more easily as well as those of her family. Her aim is to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in funds

loans.name: Peninah

texts.en:
Peninah is 32 years old. She is married and has two children, one of whom is in school. She has been running a posho mill for four years. She earns extra income as an employee in the industrial area. 

She is a member of Faulu Kenya and has learned how to save her money. She describes herself as hardworking and hopes to expand her business and earn more income from it. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add to her stock of maize.

[Editor's Note: Posho is a porridge-like food made from maize or cassava flour. A posho mill is a machine that grinds the corn or cassava into flour, so it can be made into posho.]

loans.use: To buy more maize

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Obadiah

texts.en:
Obadiah is 31 years old and married and has one child who attends school. He has been running a textile business for eight years. Previously, he worked  for the G4S Security Group, but currently he has no extra source of income.

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to expand his business and has become financially stable. He hopes to supply masses of clothes and other  textiles country-wide. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to provide a better education to his children.

He has requested a loan of Kes 90,000 to add to his stock of children’s clothes.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en:
Sarmila T. is a resident of Bhakepati. She lives in a "single family" (not with her extended family) with her husband and one son . Her son studies in grade 5.

Mrs. Sarmila and her husband opened their small restaurant three years ago. They sells Nepalese food in their restaurant. They also serve tea and coffee to their customers.

Mrs. T. is requesting a loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy food for their restaurant.

loans.use: To buy food for their restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more exercise books, ink for the printing machine and other stationery supplies.

loans.name: Rusallia

texts.en:
Rusallia is married and blessed with two children. One child usually attends school. She has been running a retail shop and a vegetable kiosk for eight years. Her business is located at Kambi Muru in Nairobi and she has one employee. She gets extra income from her husband’s salary. 

Since Rusallia joined Faulu Kenya, she has gained both financial and business management skills. She hopes to put her investment in a wholesale business in the future. She has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy maize flour, sugar, cereals, fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To add stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional African cloth for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Kanchan

texts.en:
Mrs. Kanchan K. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishipati, which is one of the developing villages of the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming.

She lives in a single family home with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Sabin K., is a house painter. They have one son and one daughter. Both of the children are studying in primary school.

Kanchan is a farmer and grows green vegetables on her land. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening. She uses her income for her children's education. Now she is requesting a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Miriam Jovana

texts.es:
Miriam tiene 27 años de edad, posee casa propia con su esposo y sus hijos, de los cuales el 
mayor se encuentra en edad escolar, y su otra niña recién nacida. Ella inicio el 
negocio hace 10 años aproximadamente con un capital pequeño, incrementándolo con el 
pasar de los años. Miriam atiende su negocio de manera muy amable y les brinda una 
buena atención, siendo la gran mayoría de sus clientes pobladores de  la zona. Miriam 
actualmente se encuentra construyendo su vivienda que fue totalmente destruida por el 
terremoto, la construcción la esta realizando con dinero ahorrado producto de las 
utilidades del negocio y el bono de reconstrucción. Solicita el  crédito para la 
compra de útiles escolares para su negocio y tambien para la compra de algunos materiales de construcción que le hacen falta.
texts.en:
Miriam is 27 years old. She lives in her own house with her husband and their children. The oldest child is school-age, and their daughter is newborn. Approximately ten years ago she started her business with a small amount of money. As the years passed she increased it. Miriam tends her business in a kind way, and she gives good service. Most of her customers are inhabitants of the area. Miriam is currently building her house, which was totally destroyed by the earthquake. The construction is being done with money she saved from her business and the reconstruction voucher. She is requesting the loan to buy school supplies for her business. She will also buy some needed construction materials.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fruits for her business

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is 44 years old and married with three children. She is a dairy and crops farmer which she has been doing for many years. She sells her farm produce to wholesalers who later sell to the small-scale traders. She also sells milk to her neighbors and retailers where she lives. Her husband, John, is also a farmer and they live in the same area, which is on the outskirts of Nairobi town. 

Hannah was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be her first loan. She has had no previous credit history with other microfinance institutions before joining KADET. She wants to use the money from this loan to buy fertilizers, seedlings and manure for the farm so that her output can increase. 

Hannah wants to be a leader in farm produce and dairy farming. This will improve their living standards and she will be able to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more seedlings, fertilizers and manure

loans.name: Vitalis Nyangoro

texts.en:
Vitalis Nyangoro is married with three children, ages 11, 6 and 1. He runs a charcoal wholesale store jointly with his wife, Pamela. He has been in this business for ten years, during which he has grown from a retailer to wholesaler.

Vitalis benefited from a previous loan from KADET which he paid well without any difficulties. He is grateful to the Kiva lenders for their support. He is now applying for another loan as he has received contracts from different schools to supply charcoal for cooking. He needs funds to be able to buy 40 sacks of charcoal and to be able to meet the demands of his customers. 

Vitalis hopes to be the leading supplier of charcoal and also to obtain more contracts from other leading institutions so as to have a constant demand for the charcoal. He also has a desire to have his children well educated at school.

loans.use: To buy 40 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods in bulk for her business

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji J.  is currently in the business of selling various items in her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more items to sell. Keji is 28 years old and is married to a clerk. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more items for sale in her shop

loans.name: Philip Mwanzali

texts.en:
Philip Mwanzali A. is 36 years old and is from Manyatta in Kisumu. He is married to Wilfrida Atieno and they have three children: Collins, who is in secondary school, and Hillary and Joy, who are both in Primary school.

Phillip has a retail shop in Manyatta area and has serviced a previous loan from Kadet Ltd, which enabled him to expand his business. He is applying for another loan which he intends to use to buy ten crates of soda for sale during the hot season as they are on high demand, and also to add more stock to his shop. His wife helps him to run the shop, and the profits they make enable them to be able to pay rent, pay school fees for their children and meet their daily needs.

He hopes to expand the business from retail to wholesale, and also to educate his children to university level, so as to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy crates of soda and add more stock to shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy wheat flower and maize flower for making butes

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is 49 years old. He is married to Margaret Nyambura and they have three children, all of whom are in college. He has operated his taxi in Naivasha town for the past five years.

Samwel was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to service his car and put a new coat of paint on it with proceeds from the loan.

He plans to start commercial farming in future.

loans.use: To service and repaint his taxi

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka S. is currently in the business of selling beans and charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more beans to sell. Nyoka is 49 years old and is widowed. She has three children, and her children go to school.  ith the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more beans to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, wheat flour and maize flour

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janet G., 29, owns a small parcel of rice farmland. She is a farmer and at the same time a retailer because she plants rice and sells various type of goods in Norralah South Cotabato. She has only one child, who is two years old. The business really helps her provide the basic needs in their home.

She hopes to receive a loan of PHP 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise and farm supplies

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy W. is 35 years old. She has been selling used clothes in Naivasha town for the past five years, and she says her business has been good. She prices her clothes with the right price for her target market. 

She got to know about KADET through one of the company's awareness campaigns in Naivasha town. This will be her third loan from KADET, and her credit history in paying loans is very good. She plans to use proceeds from this loan to add more clothes for sale, in particular men’s shirts and ladies blouses, which are on high demand.

She hopes to one day to move to a more permanent place rather than selling from the roadside.

loans.use: To buy more shirts and blouses for sale

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph C. is 28 years old. He is married to Eunice Wanjiru, and they have a 3-year-old child. 

Joseph has been in the motorcycle taxi business in Naivasha town since last year. He heard about KADET through one of the marketing promotions organized by the company, and he joined with one of the groups. He plans to use the money from the loan to buy a new helmet for his clients and renew his Public Service License (PSV). This is to comply with the new government regulation on motorcycle transport.

He plans to buy a pick up a van in future, which he will use to ferry goods to and from the market.

loans.use: To renew his PSV license and buy a new helmet

loans.name: Kebelyn

texts.es:
Kebelyn B. B., tiene la edad de 21 años, es soltera, y no tiene hijos, vive con sus padres. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de cerdos para la cría. La idea es darle el adecuado mantenimiento a los cerdos para poder desarrollar animales de mejor calidad, y obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando se vendan. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contenta con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Doña Kebelyn tiene varios años en este negocio de cría de cerdos. Ella espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productora.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Kebelyn B. B., 21, is single and doesn't have any children; she lives with her parents. She will use the loan to buy pigs to raise. The idea is to give them proper care so that they will develop into good quality animals that will command the best possible sale price when the time to sell them comes. This is her first loan with FUDECOSUR and she is very happy with the loan terms she got. Kabelyn has worked raising pigs for several years. She hopes to provide her family with a better standard of living and greater economic stability in the future as well as to continue growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional tomatoes, onions and other vegetables

loans.name: Sara Gaudiosa

texts.es:
Sara tiene 59 años de edad, es casada, tiene 5 hijos ya independizados y vive junto a su esposo en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Desde hace un año tiene instalado en su vivienda una pequeña bodega en la que ofrece a sus clientes abarrotes en general y golosinas. Su esposo se dedica a trabajar como obrero de construcción, pero como ya es de edad avanzada, no está encontrando trabajo con la misma frecuencia con la que solía encontrarlo antes. Por ese motivo su negocio es muy importante para el sostenimiento de la economía familiar.

Su bodega es muy frecuentada por sus vecinos, los cuales acuden a ella para agenciarse de productos de consumo diario por los que tendrían que ir hasta el centro de la ciudad para comprarlos, cabe resaltar que la zona en donde vive queda alejada del centro de la ciudad.

Sara desea implementar su negocio con la compra de una balanza y a la vez ampliarlo con la compra de más abarrotes, por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Ella es una mujer entregada a su familia y a su trabajo. Su mayor anhelo es seguir haciendo crecer su negocio para obtener una mejor calidad de vida y salir adelante junto a su esposo.
texts.en:
Sarah, age 59, is married and has five independent children. She lives with her husband in the Paiján district, Ascope province, La Libertad region. It is three hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. One year ago she set up a small convenience store in her house. She offers general groceries and sweets to her customers. Her husband is a construction worker. But, as he is elderly, he is not finding work as often as he did before.
