Estos grupos pagan en forman conjunta con asociaciones de socias adultas que se convierten generalmente en mentoras de las y los jóvenes.

La asociación comunal “Jesus Te Ama”, cuenta con  un grupo de Jóvenes que paga en forma paralela, esta compuesta por 2 mujeres y 2 varones. En la foto son los dos muchachos que tienen gorras y las dos jovencitas de chaqueta azul y chamarra blanca.

Omar C. Q. es el Presidente del Grupo de Jóvenes, tiene 18 años y ya tiene dos ciclos como socio.  Tiene el negocio de  carpintería y lo lleva adelante en sociedad con un amigo desde hace 5 años.  Actualmente elabora catres y veladores, pues son su especialidad.  Con su primer crédito de Bs. 1000.- recuerda haber comprado madera, ahora que su crédito es de Bs. 2000.-el esperar comprar sus propias herramientas de trabajo: martillo, cepillo (de manera) y madera que es su materia prima.
Finalmente indica que lo que más le gusta de Pro Mujer es compartir con el/las compañero/as de su grupo.
texts.en:
Asociaciones Comunales de Jovenes is a work model developed by Pro Mujer a few years ago in order to support initiatives for the self-employment of young people. This credit is meant for groups of 4 or more young people that promise, along with their parents, to solidify their guarantee. These groups pay all together, along with adult associations that generally become like mentors to these young men and women. The communal association, "Jesus Te Ama," is composed of a group of 2 girls and 2 boys, who follow this plan. In the photo, there are the two boys with caps and the two girls with a blue and a white jacket. Omar C. Q. is the president of the group of young people. He is 18 years old and has been a member for two loan cycles. He has a carpentry business that he has grown by partnering with his friend 5 years ago. Nowadays, he makes bed stands and bedside tables, which are his specialty. With his first loan of Bs1000 (he remembers having bought wood, now that his credit is Bs2000), he hopes to buy his own work tools: a hammer, a plane, and wood, his most important commodity. Finally, he states that what he likes most about Pro Mujer is spending time with the members of his group.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: wood, hammer, plane, varnish

loans.name: Jesus Te Ama Group

texts.es:
El centro focal de German Busch es un centro focal que ha sido creado hace siete años en la zona de Huayna Potosi – ciudad de El Alto.  La asociación comunal “Jesus Te Ama” ya tiene  12 ciclos (6 años) en el centro focal, está compuesto por 9 participantes adultos: 8 mujeres y 1 varón, además trabaja en forma paralela  a un grupo de 4 jòvenes: 2 mujeres y 2 varones .

La asociación  tienen diferentes negocios como zapatería, costura de polleras pequeñas, venta de juguetes, venta de repuesto para auto, costura de pollera, venta de verdura, venta de manta de vicuña, ferretería y en algunos casos comercio en general.

En el caso de la señora Rosario A., de 28 años de edad, su negocio es la venta de juguetes  “americanos”, desarrolla esta actividad desde hace un año y medio gracias a la invitación de una amiga.
Las ventas son realizadas en la zona 16 de Julio, en su Feria de los días Jueves y Domingo, por las mañanas.  Está casada y tiene 3 hijos (2 mujeres y 1 varón).  Lo que más le gusta de Pro Mujer son los cambios que incluyen el préstamo interno, rapidez en el desembolso de los créditos.
texts.en:
The central office of German Busch was created seven years ago in the Huayna Potosi zone, in the city of El Alto. The communal association, "Jesus Te Ama," has already had 12 loan cycles (6 years) in this central office. This group is composed of 9 participating adults: 8 women and 1 man, who work alongside a group of 4 young people: 2 girls and 2 boys. The association has different businesses, such as a shoe store, a skirt sewing shop, a hardware store, the sale of toys, auto parts, vegetables, blankets made with vicugna fur, and other general products. In the case of Mrs. Rosario A., of 28 years old, her business is the sale of American toys. She has been developing this business since a year and a half ago thanks to a the invitation of a friend. Her sales are done at the Zona 16 de julio Fair on Thursdays and Sundays, in the morning. She is married and has 3 children (2 girls and 1 boy). What she likes most about Pro Mujer are the changes that the internal loans have and the credits' rapid expenditure.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: American toys

loans.name: Chinara's Group

texts.en:
In the coldest part of mountainous Kyrgyzstan, just at the foot of a mountain, there is the beautiful city of Naryn. Under the Soviet Union it was somehow the capital of this country because everything was imported here first and then spread to other places. Now you can meet Russian people who speak Kyrgyz, another example that the Kyrgyz language is universal.

In this beautiful place lives our hero, Chinara I., a leader of this group. Chinara is a strong and determined woman.  She is forty-three, married and a brilliant mother of four children. They are very smart and help their mother. Her husband is a taxi driver and earns 5,000 KGS ($113) per month.

Last year they decided to sell their bull calf for 15,000 KGS ($340), thus beginning their business. Now the profit is 5,000 KGS ($113). They already have bought furniture and their plan for the future is to buy a car. They want a loan to buy two bull calves to fatten and resell.

Keneshkan K. is thirty-six, married and the mother of four children. Her husband is tractor driver. She sells provisions such as sugar, rice, oil and daily goods.  Her profit is 5,000 KGS ($113) per month. She wants to get a loan to extend her assortment.

Baktygul O. is forty-nine, married and the mother of three children. Once they needed money very much and decided to sell their cow, so they used the money and with the rest they have bought a bull calf for 10,000 KGS ($227). This was their first step into the business world. Now their revenue is 6,000 KGS ($136). They want to get a loan to buy two bull calves so that they can fatten and resell them.

Nurlanbek I. is a forty-nine year old married man with two children. His eldest is a student at a technical university and the younger one is at home. Nurlanbek has already bought a car. The business began with 10,000 KGS ($227) from selling sheep. His profit is 6,000 KGS ($136). He wants to get a loan as he wants to buy two bull calves. 

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
 
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy two bull-calves to fatten and resell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira es una mujer muy radiante de alegría, tiene 37 años y está casada con el padre de sus 3 hijos. Por el momento viven y tienen su negocio en la casa de sus suegros, pero ya compraron su propio terreno, el cual irán construyendo más adelante.

Hace 19 años trabaja en la municipalidad de su localidad como secretaria, pero paralelamente y junto a su esposo, tienen una librería y cabinas de Internet, las que atiende Edwin (su esposo) y ella lo apoya los fines de semana. La librería tiene cerca de 10 años y las cabinas de internet 8, en lo cual les va muy bien. Su esposo es un hombre que le gusta las ventas y además es muy creativo, por ello realiza diseños gráficos para diversas tiendas comerciales, y con las ganancias viene ampliando el negocio. Es por ello que Elvira lo apoya en todo, con el fin de tener pronto su casa propia.

Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, donde ratifica su compromiso responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y manifiesta su satisfacción de trabajar con los demás integrantes de su banco comunal. Con el dinero que ahora solicita va a comprar una vitrina y algunos repuestos para computadoras, para que de ese modo genere mayores ganancias en su negocio.
texts.en:
Elvira is a woman who radiates happiness. She is 37 and is married to the father of her 3 children. At the moment they live with her husband's parents and operate their business from that house as well. However, they have already bought land for themselves, on which they plan to build in the future. Elvira has worked as a secretary in her town's municipal government for 19 years. Along with her husband, however, she also runs a bookstore with internet access booths. Edwin (her husband) runs the business and she helps on the weekends. They've had the bookstore for almost 10 years and the internet access booths for 8 years, and both sides of the business do well. Elvira's husband enjoys working in sales and he is very creative. For this reason he also works as a graphic designer for various stores, using his earnings to expand his and Elvira's business. Elvira supports her husband in all these efforts, with the hope of having their own home soon. This is Elvira's fifth loan with MFP [the Kiva field partner], and she promises to be responsible with her repayments. She also mentions that she has found it satisfying to work with the other members of her Communal Bank. With the money from the current loan she will buy a glass shop window and replacement parts for computers, in order to increase the income from their business.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of replacement parts for computers

loans.name: Felicita

texts.es:
Felicita es oriunda del ande peruano, tiene 56 años y es madre de 3 hijos; 2 de ellos viven fuera y con el último vive en su una casa modesta ubicada al sur de la ciudad de Lima.

Desde que llegó a la ciudad se dedicó a infinidad de labores, pero de todas ellas la que más le dio resultado fue la venta de los productos de su zona; como la quinua, habas, maíz y otros granos. Esto lo realiza desde el puesto que tiene en el mercado de su distrito. Con esas ganancias se ha comprado utensilios adecuados para cocinar las menestras que también vende en su puesto. Gracias a esta actividad, Felicita ha podido educar a sus hijos y brindarles lo mejor, dentro de sus posibilidades, ya que no tiene pareja. Hace poco sufrió una fractura del brazo, pero espera recuperase muy pronto para seguir trabajando, mientras tanto su hijo la suple en su puesto.

Este es su 17avo préstamo con MFP y durante este tiempo ha demostrado ser una cliente muy responsable en el pago de sus cautas. Asimismo acude a todas las reuniones de su grupo, donde comparte experiencias y con sus compañeras de crédito. El dinero que ahora solicita los piensa utilizar en el incremento de su mercadería; así como algunos pagos médicos por su brazo fracturado.
texts.en:
Felicita is from the Peruvian Andes. She is 56 years old and the mother of 3 children. Two of them live on their own and the youngest lives with her in a modest house located in southern Lima. Since coming to the city, she has had countless jobs. Of all of them the one that had the best results was selling products from her area: quinoa, beans, corn and other grains. She does this in the stall she has in her district's market. With the profits, she has bought the equipment needed to cook the vegetable stews she also sells from her stall. Thanks to this activity, Felicita has been able to educate her children and offer them the best she can, since she doesn't have a husband. A short time ago, she broke her arm, but she expects to recuperate quickly and continue working. In the meantime, her son is taking over the stall. This is her 17th loan with MFP and she has shown that she is a very responsble customer with her payments. She also goes to all of the group meetings where she shares her experiences with the other loan members. She plans on using the money she is asking for now to increase her merchandise and also to pay some medical bills for her broken arm.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Luz tiene 50 años, es una madre muy amorosa para sus hijos y una buena esposa. Este mes está al cuidado de su suegra que ya es anciana, toda la familia vive en una casa alquilada.

Debido a la invitación de su hermana se inició en la venta de productos nutricionales, inicialmente no le gustaba el comercio porque era muy tímida y de poco hablar, pero tenía que hacerlo para ayudarle a cubrir los gastos familiares a su esposo, quien es carpintero. 
Ahora lleva 2 años en la venta de estos productos y logra buenas utilidades, pues ya se acostumbró a su trabajo y ha aprendido mucho sobre las técnicas de venta.
Pero el anhelo de Luz es comprar un terreno e instalar allí el taller de carpintería de su esposo, mientras ella continúa con su negocio desde casa.

Este es su 2do préstamo con MFP y promete pagar puntualmente sus cuotas, como lo hizo antes, ya que quiere ganarse la confianza de la entidad para acceder a posteriores créditos, pues son valiosos para su progreso. Con el dinero que ahora solicita incrementará la cantidad de productos nutricionales que vende y con otra parte apoyará a su esposo en la compra de madera para la fabricación de muebles.
texts.en:
Luz, age 50, is a very loving mother to her children and a good wife. This month she is taking care of her mother-in-law who is elderly. The whole family lives in a rented house. At her sister’s invitation, she started selling nutritional products. At first she did not like selling because she is very shy and does not talk a lot. But, she had to do it to help her husband cover the family expenses. Her husband is a carpenter. She has now been selling these products for two years, and she gets good profits. She is now accustomed to her work, and she has learned a lot about sales techniques. Luz’s desire is to buy a piece of land and set up a carpentry shop there for her husband while she continues with her business from home. This is her second loan with MFP. She promises to make her payments punctually, like she did before. She wants to wins the institution’s confidence in order to access loans in the future. They are valuable to her progress. She will use the money she is now requesting to increase the quantity of nutritional products that she sells. She will also help her husband buy wood for making furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Gelien

texts.en: Gelien D. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 19 years old and married. To make a living, Gelien owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Gelien has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Gelien joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gelien has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gelien is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Gelien from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Atyrkul's Group

texts.en:
Atyrkul K., the leader of the group, is a wonderful woman. She is self-confident, insistent and energetic: these features have really helped in her life, because now she has a lovely family and likes what she does. As with most women, she has dedicated her life to the benefit of her family. Now she is the mother of four children. Her elder daughter is a university student. Atyrkul wishes to help her daughter because she rents a flat and needs some money to live. The rest of her children are school students. 

Atyrkul has a marvelous husband who works as a driver in the local administration. This friendly family has a livestock business. They sell milk and cattle, so they have already bought a new house, changed all their domestic appliances and can pay their daughter’s tuition. It is the result of 25 years of labor and some money which they had at the beginning. Now they have impressive results, because their monthly revenue is 10,000 KGS ($227). They want to buy a sheep to raise by getting a loan.

Maksatbek K. is 62. He has a wife who is a pensioner and he also has children who live separately. Even though his wife is a pensioner, she sells goods in a pavilion near their house. They started their business with 25,000 KGS ($568) and now their profit is 7,000 KGS ($160) per month. He wants to get a loan to buy foodstuffs in order to trade wholesale.

Gulan K. is 40 and is divorced. She is a state clerk. She has livestock and has land on which she plans to build a house. Now she wants to get a loan to buy a cow to extend her livestock.

Gulzada A. is 43, is married and has five children. Three of her children go to the local school, the other two are at home. They plan to send her daughter to the capital for her education because they live in a village which is located far from Bishkek. They have already built a house, so they want to buy a new carpet with the loan. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Asel's Group

texts.en:
Not far from Naryn, there is a village called Kochkor. In winter there is heavy snowfall in Kochkor. Everywhere it seems to be silent and only some sounds of cattle can be heard. However, there are people there. Children make snowballs and play games. Adults are busy with their livestock.  Along with everyone else, Asel K., the leader of the group, also deals with her housework, but what makes her special is her youth and determined character. She is a purposeful individual and seeks differences in her life. She is 27 years old, married, a marvelous mother of two children and a good wife. The older child is five and her daughter is two. Her husband works as a welder in an organization, but in his free time he helps in her business. In 2009, they took out a loan to buy cattle and then sold them. For money they have two calves which they are now fattening. They started with 20,000 KGS ($446). At present their revenue is 3,000 KGS ($66) per month. Their plan is to improve their life and be more comfortable by buying a big house. However, at first they want to get a loan to buy a horse to fatten which they would sell in summer. For profit they are going to gather in a harvest crop from the field which they have already bought. 

Kubatbek A. is a married man aged 60. His wife is a pensioner. They have a son who helps them. They resell potatoes in the market and have already bought a car for 42,000 KGS ($940). They want to invest the loan to increase turnover which is currently 150,000 KGS ($3,400).

Aida J. K. is 34 and has three children. The elder two attend school and the youngest one is at home. Her husband is a member of a peasant household. She has a business which she began three years ago. She buys old pictures and remakes them for selling. She started with 5,000 KGS ($112) and her profit per month is 5,000 KGS ($112).  They have bought a car for 45,000 KGS ($1,004). She wants to get a loan to invest in her business.

Nurgul I. is 36 and the mother of four children. They all attend the local school. Her husband is a member of peasant households. They have bought a tractor for 50,000 KGS ($1,117). Now she fattens cattle. They began with 20,000 KGS ($446) and now the revenue is 3,000 KGS ($66). By taking out the loan they want to buy cattle to fatten and sell afterwards.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Lofty goals require big efforts. Sometimes in order to reach your goal you have to put up with temporary obstacles and get used to rough conditions. However, provided that there is determination to keep going and readiness to sacrifice personal comfort, the result does not let the person down. The question is whether he or she is ready to go beyond the usual conditions and take a risk. Once they make this decision, go through this path and achieve success, their stories become models for others to follow.

Elmira is the leader of this group. She is 43 years old. Elmira and her family live in the city of Tokmok. Her husband manufactures metal instruments and has a monthly salary of $50. Elmira’s daughter rents space in a big shop and sells bijouterie (jewelry). She manages to make $80. Elmira’s son is 14 and studies in the seventh grade. Some years ago Elmira started with selling children’s clothes and later on switched to trading in men’s and women’s clothes. This business provides her with a monthly income of $350. Elmira hopes to obtain this loan and invest the funds to increase the turnover by buying more kinds of clothes for the upcoming spring season. Her future plans are to buy a flat and provide her son with a college education. Elmira’s partners are: Saikal is 41, divorced and has two daughters. To provide for her daughters and her elderly mother, Saikal sells potatoes in the local market. She brings potatoes from another region. Saikal needs a loan to be able to bring more potatoes. Kuljan is 38, divorced and has a daughter. Kuljan trades in bed clothing. She also manufactures national articles and manages to earn $160. Kuljan needs a loan as she wants to buy more bed clothing. Rayimbek is 23, married and has a newborn daughter. Until now he has been trading in cattle with his brother and sharing the income. He decided to take out a loan and start his own business. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
A big success starts with small steps. People who want much at once are doomed to disappointment, because a big role belongs to patience and resolution, The heroes of this story cannot boast grandiose success in their lives, but they are on that path.

Farida is the leader of this group. She is thirty-four years old. She lives in the small city of Tokmok. Many people of her age have left the city to work in Russia or neighboring Kazakhstan. Farida and her husband, despite a very difficult economic condition and poor job opportunities, have decided to stay in the city. At this moment her husband earns his family’s living by working as a taxi driver. Farida owns a pavilion. She trades in vegetables and different kinds of foodstuffs. Trading in the pavilion brings her a monthly income of $230. During her twenty years of selling vegetables, Farida has been able to buy a flat and a car. At this moment she needs a loan to purchase foodstuffs and vegetables. Farida lives with her family in a detached house and some of her future plans are to make a repair at her house, buy new furniture and put up new gates.

The following people are Farida’s partners:

Alymkan is fifty-two. Her husband is a taxi driver. Alymkan would happily stay at home and be a housewife; however, working as a taxi driver brings her husband only $140, so Alymkan decided to help her husband by selling patties. Alymkan needs a loan to increase the turnover.

Elmira is thirty-four. She has two daughters, both of whom go to school. Her husband provides welding services. Elmira is engaged in a furniture business. She purchases old furniture, repairs it, and resells it at market. This business brings her $185 a month. Elmira needs a loan to invest in her business.

Nurkanbek is twenty-two. He is single. For a living he manufactures small chests in his own workshop and takes the chests to Bishkek to sell them there. Nurkanbek has applied for this loan as he hopes to buy materials for manufacturing.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of their customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our lending team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma R. is from the village of San Juan, Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies, and this time, Gemma's husband managed their motorcycle used to transport passengers in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gemma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI; that previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gemma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
Among the multitude of people who surround us, it is quite difficult to know that there are people who are in need of little help. Sometimes you are able to help them. and just because you are not familiar with them. you just walk beside these people not even realizing who they are, and therefore reading these stories is a real way to help people.

The heroes of this story are ordinary people from Kyrgyzstan. S. Nurjan, 31, is the leader of this group. She comes from Tokmok, a provincial town in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has two sons. Her husband works in the military; he is a foreman. Both of Nurjan’s sons were too little to go to school and Nurjan had to stay at home and look after the children. Nevertheless, Nurjan’s sister advised her to start a trade in something, so about two years ago, Nurjan started trading in shoes and socks. Now she has a stable income of about seventy dollars per month. This has allowed her to save some funds and buy some items of furniture for the house. Nurjan is in need of a loan. She would like to invest some funds that would help her to buy more kinds of shoes and socks, which in turn would boost her sales. In near future she is planning to buy a car. Her plans go as far as to buy a three–room flat.

These people are Nurjan’s partners:

Ayim is twenty-seven. She lives in Tokmok. Her spouse works in the Border Service of the Kyrgyz Republic. Ayim has a son. Ayim has been fortunate. Due to her husband’s job, she sent her son to a kindergarten and started trading in men’s and women’s shoes. Ayim hopes to obtain this loan and invest the funds to increase the turnover.

Gulnara is 32. She has two children. Since the collapse of Soviet Union, she has been engaged in commerce near a hospital. Now, she plans to sell foodstuffs at school. She needs a loan to purchase goods and foodstuffs to increase the turnover. With the return, she will pay for her daughter’s education.

Anara is fifty. Her husband took part in the Afghan war and now is retired. Anara has three children. Her eldest daughter goes to high school. The rest are little and stay at home with Anara. Anara needs a loan to make a repair in her flat.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of their customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our lending team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy more kinds of shoes and socks

loans.name: Arce

texts.en:
Arce Q. is from the village of Kahulugan, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old. Arce is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Arce owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Arce has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Arce joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arce has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI; that loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Arce is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arce from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Siyagul's Group

texts.en:
If you ask any person about what he expects, you usually get an answer that he or she hopes to finish school, go to college, find a good job, gradually get promoted and become a boss. However, this ideal path awaits not everybody. And whoever it would be, a person has to be ready to any turn and any situation. The strong people do not expect or dream much about less probable things and just use the best use of the opportunities that life presents for them.

Siyagul is the leader of this group. Siyagul lives in Tokmok, which is located in the north of Kyrgyzstan, near the border with Kazakhstan. She is fifty-two and has a son. Her son is a grown–up and works in the local municipality. He lives separately from his parents as he has already got an accommodation for himself. Siyagul and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. They have been doing this for the last fifteen years and have increased the total population of their livestock. Siyagul has decided to apply for a loan as she is in need of some funds to invest in purchasing 4 sheep for feeding. As the spring is approaching, it is the most suitable time to make such purchases.

Siyagul’s partners are:

Rahat is twenty-nine. Her spouse provides for the family by working as a taxi driver. Rahat is a mother of two children. She also trades in electric supplies. She has two spots at the local market. Rahat manages to earn about $570 a month. She hopes to obtain this loan and buy more electric goods.

Munara is thirty-five. She has two sons. Together with her husband, Munara keeps cattle, and on weekends they sell cattle in the market. Munara has applied for this loan as she hopes to buy some more cattle for feeding and resale.

Adylbek is forty-three. Adylbek’s wife is a saleswoman. They have three children. Adylbek owns a container and also trades in consumer goods. They hope to obtain this loan and invest it in purchasing goods.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of their customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our lending team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase 4 sheep for feeding

loans.name: Sevil

texts.en: Sevil M. was born in 1954. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, and is now settled in Baku city. She is married and has three children. Sevil has been in the tailoring business for four years. She is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy cloth and other items to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy cloth and other items to improve her business

loans.name: Safina

texts.en:
Safina is a 47-year-old married woman with eight children aged between 18 and 32 years. Two of her children go to school while the others work. Safina also takes care of additional family members. She owns a four-roomed house where she lives with 12 people. There is electricity and piped water at her home, and her family eat three meals a day. Safina lives and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. Her major monthly expenses include rent for her business premises and water.
Safina is a poultry farmer and works seven days a week from her home in Kulambiro. She sells to an average of 20 customers a day. Safina buys her chicks from farmers in Biyinzika, and uses public transport to and from Kampala and Owino market where she buys chicken feed. She has been in this business for the last six years. Her main challenges are thieves and seasonality. Safina has been with Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, for over six years and is now on her sixteenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more feed and chickens. Her aspiration is to own 3,000 chickens on her farm.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feed

loans.name: Erkebubu's Group

texts.en:
Mutual assistance has been one of the most effective ways to struggle against poverty all over the world. Probably the main problem that causes most of the uprisings and revolts in Third World countries is the expanding rupture between the rich and the poor. So, what the microfinance organizations have been doing has greatly relieved the situation, as it has given tens of millions of people an opportunity to start their business and improve their standard of living. An amount of money that may seem nothing to a rich businessman, who spends this sum every day having lunch in a restaurant, is to another person vital initial capital, with which he or she could start a new life. And that’s what makes this life interesting!

Erkebubu is the leader of this loan group. She is 49 and the mother of two children. She is raising her children on her own as she has been divorced for the last few years. To provide for her little family, Erkebubu produces national milk soft drinks – “bozo” and “maksym” (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrgyz_cuisine for more information). This seemingly small business has allowed her to make repairs in her apartment. Now her monthly income has reached $420. Erkebubu needs a loan to increase the amount of drinks she sells. She hopes to save money to buy strawberry seedlings.

Erkebubu’s partners are:
Gulmira, 38, is divorced. She has two children and needs a loan for personal use. She is planning to purchase furniture.
Erkingul, 34, is a mother of two children. Her husband provides welding services. Erkingul is engaged in network marketing and sells perfumes, cosmetics and detergents. She is requesting a loan to purchase goods and also buy a TV set with plasma screen.
Chinara is the youngest member of this group at 25 years old. She works as a saleswoman selling bed clothing and dishes. She decided to apply for a loan after her sister advised her to purchase more goods to attract more customers. Chinara’s current monthly income is $185.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To increase the amount of milk soft drinks she sells

loans.name: Sadaina

texts.en:
Sadaina is a married woman with four children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with six people. They have electricity but no piped water at home. The family eats three meals a day. 

Sadaina works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She operates a retail shop in Kampala city where she sells bed sheets. She will use her loan to buy more products for her shop. Sadaina works six days a week and sells to an average of 15 customers a day. She uses public transport to and from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. Sadaina has been in this business for the past ten years and has been with Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, for five years. She is now on her twelfth loan and her main monthly expenses include rent for accommodation, daily market dues, school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise such as bed sheets  for her retail shop

loans.name: Mayramkul's Group

texts.ru:
Когда во всём мире происходят перемены, и меняются жизненный уклад целых стран, отдельные люди в силу своих интеллектуальных способностей также начинают реагировать на эти изменения. Когда в странах бывшего советского союза началась меняться экономика, жизненный уклад и идеология, наиболее дальновидные люди сразу осознали необходимость заняться частным предпринимательством. Герои этой истории, оказались таковыми, так как в основном все решили работать на рынке. Молдокматова Майрамкуль – лидер группы. Майрамкуль вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Карабалта. У Майрамкуль трое детей: сын и две дочери. Майрамкуль и её муж нашли свою нишу в животноводстве. Они решили заняться перепродажей и откормом крупно – рогатого скота и занимаются этим последние шесть лет. А начали они с того, что сначала продали корову, которая у них была ранее, и купили двух бычков и занялись откормом. Сейчас от перепродажи скота они имеют доход в размере четырнадцати тысяч сомов. За последние годы они смогли приобрести авто и за счёт этого бизнеса обучают младшую дочь в университете, оплачивая её контракт. Старший сын уехал работать в Южную Корею, среднюю дочь выдали замуж, а младшая учится в университете, и параллельно работает парикмахером. Сейчас Майрамкуль и её муж нуждаются в кредите,  чтобы вложить кредитные средства в покупку 1-й коровы для дальнейшей перепродажи на рынке. В будущем они планируют построить  большой дом. 

У Майрамкуль три партнёра по группе:

Турусову Бакытбеку сорок два года. Супруга Бакытбека уехала на заработки в Россию. Бакытбек отец двух детей. Дети уже подросли. Сын работает на стройке, а дочь учится в колледже. Сам Бакытбек предоставляет услуги столяра, продаёт  изделия из дерева, ручки для топора, каталки и доски. Бакытбеку нужен кредит, чтобы купить стройматериалы.

Абдыкаимовой Салиме сорок два года. Салима мать четверых детей. Муж Салимы, работает грузчиком на рынке. Дочери работают в швейном цеху, один из сыновей ходит в школу, а другой пока ещё дошкольник. Салима занимается розничной торговлей картошки и обратилась за кредитом ,чтобы закупить картошки для продажи.

Абдыракмановой Азизахан сорок два года. Вместе с мужем они торгуют овощами на базаре. Азизахан растит пятерых детей. Старшие уже достаточно подросли, чтобы помогать родителям в торговле. Азизахан нуждается в кредите, так как ей нужны средства, чтобы закупить фрукты для увеличения ассортимента товара.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
When the whole world is changing and the way of life of entire nations is transformed, competent individuals also begin to react to the developments. When the economy, way of life, and ideology of the post-Soviet countries began to change, the most farsighted people immediately recognized the necessity of taking up private enterprise. The heroes of this story were such people; the majority of them decided to work at the market. Mayramkul M. is the leader of this group. Together with her family Mayramkul lives in the city of Karabalta. Mayramkul has three children: a son and two daughters. Mayramkul and her husband found their niche in animal husbandry. They decided to fatten and re-sell livestock and they have been in the business for the last six years. When they were starting out, they sold their cow to buy two bull-calves and fatten them up. Today they have an income of about 14 thousand som from the re-sale of animals. In the last few years they have been able to buy a car and through this business they have the means to send their youngest daughter to the university, paying her tuition. The oldest son is working in South Korea; the middle daughter is married; the youngest daughter is studying at a university and working as a hairdresser. Mayramkul and her husband need the loan to buy a cow for re-sale on the market. In the future they plan to build a large house. Mayramkul has three partners in the group: Bakytbek T. is 42 years old. Bakytbek's wife went to Russia to earn money. Bakytbek is the father of two grown children. The son works in construction, the daughter is in college. Bakytbek himself is a carpenter and sells objects made of wood such as handles for axes, dough rollers, and cutting boards. Bakytbek needs the loan to buy construction materials. Salima A. is 42 years old; she is the mother of four children. Salima's husband works as a loader at the market. Her daughters work in a sewing shop; one of her sons goes to school and the other is a preschooler. Salima sells potatoes and is requesting the loan to purchase potatoes to sell. Azizakhan A. is 42 years old. Together with her husbans she sells vegetables at the market. Azizakhan has five children. The older children are old enough to help their parents with business. Azizakhan needs to loan in order to buy fruit to increase the selection of her goods. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding in order to resale it later

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional bags of charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 45 years of age and is married with seven children. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with her children and additional family members. She also take cares of her grandchild. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent for the house.
Edith roasts beef in Nakawa market. She has been in this business for over four years now and serves about 20 customers per day. Her main challenges are price fluctuations for commodities which, in turn, force her to raise the prices of her beef (muchomo). She has been with Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, for over three years and this is her sixth loan. She wants to use the loan to buy more beef for roasting, and hopes to expand her business given the capital.

loans.use: To buy more beef for roasting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional tomatoes, onions and other commodities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional wheat flour and maize flour

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 50-year-old married mother of five children between 14 and 26 years of age, three of whom go to school. Sarah resides with eight people in her five-roomed house that has electricity but no piped water. She also takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day.

Working seven days a week, Sarah sells charcoal in her community of Katanga, located on the outskirts of Kampala, to an average of 15 customers daily. She also practices outside catering, incurring extra transport costs to and from shopping. The major challenges she faces in her business are transportation and rising food prices.

Sarah has been with MCDT for five years, servicing her eleventh loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal and stock non-perishable foodstuffs. Sarah aspires to expand her business and owin a permanent business structure in place of the open stall she currently works from.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal and stock foodstuffs for her outside catering business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional stock of goods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional beer for her business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 30 years old and married. She has three children between the ages of 2 and 10. Two of her children go to school.  Monica also takes care of two of her sister’s children and her old mother.  She rents and lives in a two-room house with six people.  They neither have electricity nor piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day. Monica's monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala, selling new clothes in mobile markets to an average of fifteen customers day. She sells to all categories of people mainly on a retail basis. Monica started this business seven years ago and has managed to improve her family's standard of living.  

She uses public transportation to and from work. This presents a problem because at times the buses are delayed. Monica wants to use this loan to buy more clothes to sell. She hopes to see her business grow bigger so that she can own a permanent place to work .

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional inventory in bulk

loans.name: Heyder

texts.en: Heydar M. is 31 years old. He is married and has two children. M.'s family lives in the Absheron region. He has been in this business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy four calves to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy four calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal in bulk .

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a 45-year-old single mother of four children between 15 and 28 years of age, three of whom attend school. She lives with five people in a rented one-room house that has electricity but no piped water. The family gets three meals a day.

Living and working in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala, Alex sells milk seven days a week in Nakulabye Market to an average of 25 people a day. Alex buys milk from diaries in Kawempe, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, using public transport to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include the family rent, school fees and food for the family, She has been in this business for the last ten years, and her main challenge is the rainy season which stops her customers from coming to her.

Alex has been with MCDT for over five years and is servicing her thirteenth loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of milk and is hoping to expand her business and eventually own a permanent home which will act as her business premises. .

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional wheat flour, rice and beans

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a 42-year-old married woman with eight children aged between 15 and 25 years. Four of her children go to school. Aisha resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with ten people. There is no electricity or piped water at home. She takes care of additional family members and the family gets one meal a day.

Aisha resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week. She sells cold drinks and receives thirty customers a day. She doesn’t incur extra transport costs to and from shopping.

The major challenges Aisha faces in her business are monthly rent, medication, thieves, feeding the family and the increasing prices of clothes.

Aisha has been in her business for five years and with MCDT for seven years. She is servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to stock more drinks.

Aisha is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda, passion fruit and mineral water

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married with four children including a set of twins. All her children go to school. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with seven people and doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has access to electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day.

Esther operates a retail shop in Mulago and that is how she earns a living. She works seven days a week and has done this business for four years now. She doesn’t incur any transport expenses as she lives near where she shops.

Esther receives about twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. Her monthly expenses include a license for the business premises, rent for her home and business, feeding the family, and school fees.

This is Esther’s third loan since she joined MCDT and she has been with MCDT for one-and-a-half years. She wants to use this loan to buy more home products for resale.

Esther is aspiring to seeing her business growing bigger and also starting a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 41-year-old single mother of five children aged between 14 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she lives with four people. There is electricity and piped water at her home and the family gets three meals a day.

Margaret resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She sells secondhand clothes and sells door-to-door. She works seven days a week and sells to an average of twenty people a day. She buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city, incurring extra transport cost to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include rent, electricity and medication.

Margaret has been in this business for the last twenty years and sells to all categories of people. Her main challenges are the increasing prices of clothes and business seasonality. Prior to this business, she was selling charcoal.

Margaret has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy a bale of clothes and aspires to own permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with seven children. Two of her children go to school. Rose resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she lives with four people. There is no electricity or piped water at home but the family gets three meals a day.

Rose resides and works in a semi-urban area that is in the outskirts of Kampala. She runs a retail shop and works seven days a week, receiving thirty customers a day. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping in Kikuubo, one the busiest places in Kampala. The major challenges she faces in her business are transport costs and seasonality.

Rose has been in this business for six years and with MCDT also for six years. She is servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her store like sugar, salt, soap, and other items. Rose is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and owning a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, soap, and other items for her store.

loans.name: Cossy

texts.en:
Cossy is a  single mother with four children. Three of her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with ten people. She also takes care of additional family members. The Family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Cossy works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a ladies’ salon in Katanga in Wandegeya. She incurs  transport costs to and from buying hair conditioners and hair relaxers from shops in Kampala city. She sells both retail and wholesale.

Cossy works seven days a week and receives an average of five customers a day. Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of cosmetics and the rainy season which disturbs her work because she works from a muddy place. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.

Cossy has been in this business for over five years. Cossy joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start a bridal salon. Cossy is pictured with a customer.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics and hair conditioners

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a leader of four members of a group. She is a  married woman with two children , both going to school. She resides in and rents a three-roomed house where she lives with five people. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Rose resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She sells charcoal in Ndeeba market in one of the Kampala suburbs and works seven days a week. She sells to an average of twenty people a day and sells to all categories of people. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from suppliers who get the charcoal from villages. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for her business, and feeding the family.

Rose has been in this business for the last seven years and has been with MCDT for over six years. She is servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more charcoal.

Rose is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and offloading a full lorry (truck) of charcoal.
Rosde was posing with one of her groupmates and was putting on a red T.shirt with a white head gear

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is a 45-year-old married woman with five children aged from 10 to 16 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water at her home and gets three meals a day.

Eva resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She sells yellow bananas in Nakawa market in one of the Kampala suburbs. She sells to an average of twenty people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from suppliers who get their supplies from villages. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for her business, and feeding the family.

Eva has been in this business for the last seven years and has been with MCDT for over six years. She is servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.

Eva is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and offloading a full lorry (truckload) of bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas to sell

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
31-year-old Venus N. is a married woman with a four-year-old child. She lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur and owns a farm there. Aside from rice farming, she also runs a stall in the market where she sells pork and cow’s meat.

Venus shared that she is in need of additional capital for her farm. She applied to CEVI and requested a loan of Php 6,000. She said she would use this loan to buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs she needs for her rice farm.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita manages a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice farm. She is 50 years old, is married and has six children. She looks for other ways to earn extra income so she can provide for the growing needs in her household.

Amelita also works hard to maintain her farm and hopefully expand it if she has the resources. She is requesting to loan PHp 6,000 from CEVI, which she will use to fund her farm. She said she would buy farm inputs with it like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita, 54 years old, has been farming for a decade. This is what she and her husband do for a living. She works hard for her family, especially her children: she wants all of them to finish college and have a bright future.

Angelita is grateful to have gained access to CEVI’s program. She said she likes it because of the low interest rate, which will really help her earn from her farm. She requested Php 6,000, which will be used to purchase farm supplies such as seed, fertilizer and other items.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is 48 years old and is married with four children aged between 12 and 18 years. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she lives with five people. The family has no access to electricity or to piped water but gets three meals a day.

Teopista sells bananas in Ndeeba market and doesn’t incur any transport costs because she buys from her place of work. She has been in this business for fourteen years and works six days a week, selling to an average of twenty customers a day.

Teopista has been with MCDT for six years and is servicing her thirteenth loan working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas and aspires to start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas to sell

loans.name: Arminda

texts.en:
50-year-old Arminda doesn’t mind the heat when working at her farm. She said if she didn’t work, her family would not have something to eat. She helps her husband maintain their rice farm and both of them want to have an abundant harvest.

Arminda recently joined CEVI because, from what she heard, its programs have helped a lot of farmers in her community and it also offers a low interest rate. She is requesting Php 6,000 and, with this amount, she will be able to acquire farm inputs like fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like fertilizer

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty has been involved in rice farming for six years now. She is 31 years old and the mother of four children, her oldest child being only eleven years old. She is determined to send all her children to school and have them finish college.

Betty joined CEVI to gain access to its programs. She also said that the biblical reflection helps her get through times of crisis. Right now, she is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to buy seed, fertilizers and other farm inputs she needs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso works hard to feed his family. He has three children whom he wants to be given proper education. His oldest child is only six years old but he wants to start saving for their future early.

Celso is a rice farmer and also raises pigs for a living. He is grateful that, after three years, his hog-raising business is starting to grow. Now he requests a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI which he will use to buy farm supplies and also piglets and feed for his pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies as well as piglets and feed for his pigs

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Like other entrepreneurs, Dina wants to be successful in her business. She is into rice farming and is currently preparing her land for planting. At 25, she has a child to look after. She wants to grow her rice farm, which is located in Agusan Del Sur.

In need of additional capital, Dina requested Php 6,000 from CEVI which she said she would use for seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Eleanor

texts.en:
Eleanor tills a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field in her town in Agusan Del Sur. She is 40 years old and has three children. Her oldest is only 10 years old and she hopes that all of them will be able to finish college someday.

Eleanor works hard at her farm to make it productive. It is the only source of income her family has so she spends all day making sure the farm is free of weeds and pests. She also sought the help of CEVI, a micro-finance institute in the Philippines. She requested Php 6,000 that she would use for farm supplies like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has been married to Arcelito for thirty years now. She is 53 years old and has five children, her oldest being 27 years old. She is involved in rice farming and she helps her husband till their 1.5 hectares (3.75 acres) of rice field.

The needs in Elizabeth’s family are growing so she works hard to help provide for them. One of the challenges she currently faces is her children’s education. The rates of school fees get higher every year so she makes sure to have income from her farm.

Elizabeth requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). She told CEVI that she would use the loan to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Fidel

texts.en:
A married man with three children, Fidel has to earn to provide for his family’s needs.

Fidel struggled during his first years of farming but he didn’t give in despite the challenges he faced. He worked hard and now earns from his rice farm.

Fidel was seeking financial support for his business and was introduced to CEVI by his fellow farmers. He is requesting to loan Php 6,000. This loan will be used for fertilizer and other farm inputs he needs for his rice farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Gil

texts.en:
40-year-old Gil R. is a rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. He is married and has two children.

Gil started farming for a living in 1993. The farm is the only source of income Gil’s family has so he makes sure it is always productive.

Now Gil has started planting already and still needs farm inputs. He requested a loan from CEVI of Php 6,000 which he will use it to buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Irish

texts.en: Irish is the mother to a 7-year-old child. She lives in the Veruela municipality of Agusan del Sur. In 2005, she ventured into farming, and it has been her family's source of income ever since. Now, she also raises pigs to have an extra source of income. She wants to improve her income in order to help improve her family's living conditions. She requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to fund her farm. This loan will increase the working capital for her farm.

loans.use: To increase the working capital for her farm

loans.name: Jotham

texts.en: Jotham thanks God for his 2.5-hectare rice field that he currently tills. He said it has been his family's source of income for years now. He spends most of his time at the farm, because he has goals to achieve. He has children who go to school, and he wants them to finish college and have a bright future. He currently needs additional capital for his farm. So, he applied for a loan from CEVI. He said that with the amount of 6000 PHP, he would be able to buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies he needs.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: "So far, my rice farm has been running smoothly, and I am grateful that it helps my family a lot," shares Julie M., a 45-year-old married woman with five children. She wants to have a happy home. Her children's education is one of her top priorities. She wants them to experience wellness in life. She just started preparing her land for the planting of rice crops. She said that she needs supplies for it. As a new member of CEVI, she now has access to its program. So, she requested a loan of 6000 PHP. With that amount, she can buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina is a 52-year-old married woman with five children. She manages a rice farm located in her town in the province of Agusan del Sur. She seeks other ways to earn in order to provide for all her family's needs, but her focus right now is the rice farm that she tills. Her children go to school, and she does her best to keep up with the increasing school fees. She found out from her friends that a microfinance institution has been helping them with their businesses. She joined also, in order to gain access to its program. She is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP. She said she would use the money to buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies needed for her rice farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa is a 37-year-old entrepreneur from the province of Agusan del Sur. She manages a rice farm and a rice mill. She has two children with her husband, Melanio. In her spare time, she also does some food processing, which she started by using income from her rice farm. She does all this to provide for her family's needs, especially her children's education.

Ma. Theresa is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP. This is her first time to ask for a loan, and she will use it to fund her farm. She said she will buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Cesar Eduardo

texts.es: Cesar tiene 26 años es soltero no tiene carga familiar cuenta con buenas referencias personales, vive en casa de sus padres tiene amplia experiencia en el transporte ya que uno de sus sueños es adquirir su propia movilidad, trabaja como chofer alquilando una movilidad hace mas de 6 años , a Cesar le gusta mantener en buen estado su herramienta de trabajo , tiene experiencia crediticia con montos pequeños,solicita dicho credito para invertir en el mejoramiento de su dormitorio, se propone por contar con capacidad y sobre todo voluntad de pago.
texts.en:
Cesar, age 26, is single and does not have family responsibilities. He has good personal references. He lives in his parents’ house. He has vast experience in transportation. One of his dreams is to acquire his own vehicle. For over six years he has rented a vehicle and worked as a driver. He has credit history with small loans. He is asking for the loan to improve his bedroom. He is able and willing to pay his loan back.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Impove his bedroom

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn experienced failure as a farmer, but she continues to work hard for her family. Still 23 years old, she said she has a lot to learn about managing a business, especially a rice farm. She sought help from her parents and other farmer friends so she could maintain the farm she tills. She was also able to join an MFI that supports entrepreneurs like her. She applied to CEVI and asked for a loan of 6,000 PHP, which she would use for farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers. She said that having this loan is really helpful in running her business.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean, age 30, owns a one-hectare rice field. She also maintains another eight hectares from which she also earns extra income. Together with her husband, she spends the whole day tilling the farm and making sure it is free of weeds and pests to ensure that their rice crop grows healthily. She said that she works hard for her three children. She wants them to have a proper education and a bright future. She was also able to start a small store, which she hopes will grow soon.

Mary Jean is asking for a loan of 6000 PHP. She will use it to buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies. She is also hoping to add supplies to her store.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies

loans.name: Melvin

texts.en: Melvin is a 28-year-old rice farmer from the province of Agusan del Sur. He is married and has a 3-year-old child. He spends his time at the farm to make sure it is healthy for growing rice crops. He was also able to start food processing, which he hopes to expand. His wife manages the food processing, and it gives them an extra source of income. Melvin is seeking a loan of 6000 PHP. He will use it to supply his farm with seeds, fertilizer, and other needed supplies.

loans.use: To supply his farm with seeds, fertilizer, and other needed supplies

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en: Miriam is now a widow, but that doesn't stop her from continuing to provide for her family. At age 55, she still manages to run a rice farm. She has three children to look after, and the oldest child helps her maintain their farm. She wants to improve her family's living conditions. She is grateful to have gained access to CEVI, which she thinks has helped a lot of farmers like her. She requested a loan of 6000 PHP. With this amount, Miriam can buy the necessary farm supplies she needs, like seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy necessary farm supplies, like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en:
Petronila, age 46, manages a rice field and a rice mill. Now a widow, she is left with seven children. Her oldest child does not live with her anymore. She keeps herself strong in order to bear the hard work required at the farm and the mill. Her older children also help her manage the business.

Petronila wants to improve her income. So, she applied to CEVI. She is asking for a loan of 6000 PHP. She will use that loan to buy fertilizer and other needed farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other needed farm supplies

loans.name: Robilyn

texts.en: Robilyn, photographed in a rice field, is married to Andres, and they have a 3-year-old child. She raises pigs for a living, and she also runs a small store. She wants to be actively involved in her business. So, she finds ways to maintain it and to, hopefully, make it grow. She recently joined CEVI to have financial support. She requested a loan of 6000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy pig feed and additional piglets. She also hopes to add supplies to her store.
